text.p: Retired admiral Didier Ratsiraka took office on Sunday following his victory in Madagascar's presidential election last December.

To mark his return to the office that he held for 18 years before being voted out in 1993, Ratsiraka, 60, participated in a service at the Antananarivo Cathedral attended by national leaders, diplomats and visiting personalities.

Ratsiraka narrowly won the December 29 run-off in the presidential election against Albert Zafy -- the man who succeeded him as president in 1993 only to be impeached by his own parliament last year for exceeding his powers under the constitution.
Ratsiraka's 18-year rule ended when Zafy won the island's first multi-party polls in 1993, after months of unprecedented political protest which brought turmoil to the Indian Ocean island republic.
Ratsiraka later went into voluntary exile in France, but returned to run for re-election after Zafy's impeachment.
For most of his first period as president Ratsiraka was a convinced Marxist whose policies helped wreck the economy of the world's fourth-largest island.
Prime minister Norbert Ratsirahonana, who had functioned as acting president pending confirmation of the election result, offered his government's resignation on Saturday.

Officials said his resignation was a formality, intended to leave Ratsiraka, 60, the freedom to pick his own cabinet team. But Ratsirahonana and his ministers will remain in day-to-day charge of government business until a new government is announced.

The National Assembly has been summoned to meet on Monday to enable parliamentary groups to submit a list of candidates from which the president will select the new prime minister, before members of the new government are named.
The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, sent Ratsiraka a message of congratulations, officials said.

Camdessus advised the incoming president of one of the world's poorest countries to "pursue healthy financial policies as the only way left to Madagascar to create, at last, a suitable framework for development and the well-being of its people."
